Having previously served as a Mentor at GSSoC'24 and contributed to multiple projects — including Capstone Projects associated with IIT Patna and IBM — I was excited to continue my journey in GSSoC'25 to empower, guide, and uplift budding developers in their open-source journey.

As someone who has benefited immensely from community-driven platforms, I joined GSSoC’25 to mentor new contributors, share best practices, and help them grow both technically and personally.

2. Cultivating Future Leaders:
Guiding students through real-world projects helps them gain confidence and clarity. It’s fulfilling to watch beginners become confident coders under my mentorship.

3. Strengthening Open-Source Impact:
Through GSSoC'24 and now GSSoC'25, I’ve had the opportunity to work on meaningful projects like Waste Management Solutions and AI-Based Capstone Initiatives, proving how collaborative code can solve real-world problems.

4. Enhancing My Mentorship Skills:
Mentoring not only refines my technical understanding but also enhances my communication, leadership, and conflict-resolution abilities — vital for any tech professional.

5. Creating a Ripple Effect:
By mentoring in programs like GSSoC, I aim to create a ripple effect of learning and contribution that goes beyond just one project or one season — but shapes the future of open-source in India and beyond.

My mentorship journey has been rooted in the belief that guidance, when paired with empathy, can transform learning curves into growth curves. 

In my role as a Coding Mentor at SheCanCode; I have been guiding women in tech, globally through the platform's Mentorship program by conducting live coding sessions, reviewing PRs, coordinating collaborative projects, helping debug code, and supporting mentees in understanding software architecture and version control workflows. I coordinate collaborative development of my team using Git/GitHub, and support issue resolution through code reviews and peer programming. 
I have gained my Open-Source experience while contributing to tools and features ( projects) at Keploy, where I gained practical exposure in debugging, API testing, and open collaboration.I have worked on projects & features, and documented testing/debugging workflows.

Through these roles, I’ve mentored individuals at varying skill levels and built a mentorship style focused on clarity, patience, and confidence-building. My goal is always to make open-source feel accessible, not intimidating; and I’m excited to bring this experience to GSSoC 2025 to help contributors thrive from day one.
reason:
GirlScript’s mission of democratizing access to quality education and encouraging open-source diversity deeply resonates with my own journey in tech. As someone who found confidence through supportive communities and real-world learning, I recognize the power of mentorship in shaping not just careers, but mindsets. GSSoC’s inclusive and beginner-friendly environment is exactly the kind of space I would be proud to contribute to; not just as a mentor, but as a guide, advocate, and teammate.

Over the past few months, I’ve mentored women in tech globally through SheCanCode; reviewing codes, guiding projects & taking coding sessions. I'm also currently working as a Developer Intern and Team Lead, heading a full-stack development team at Bharat Economic Forum under my manager; hence handling development tasks along with reviewing issues, managing PR workflows, handling merge conflicts etc. My Open-Source journey includes contributing to tools and features (in projects) at Keploy, where I gained practical exposure in debugging, API testing, and open collaboration. With experience across domains like AI, cloud infrastructure, and scalable software development, I bring both technical depth (MERN stack, CI/CD, APIs, Git/GitHub, AWS) and the soft skills essential to inclusive mentorship; empathy, leadership, and clear communication. I believe mentorship is more than code reviews; it's about empowering others with problem-solving confidence, nurturing best practices, and fostering a sense of belonging.

By joining GSSoC 2025 as a mentor, I aim to pay it forward; to help new contributors overcome the same hurdles I once faced, and to cultivate a generation of developers who not only write great code but feel seen, supported, and inspired. GirlScript is more than a program; it's a movement; and I want to be an active part of it.

about:
Who am I? I am Sayanabha Chandra, and,

It took me more than 4 years of engineering and 1 year of real-world experience to truly understand the ins and outs of development, but since then, I've realized that the real magic happens in the designs that make users feel truly connected.

I design a lot. And that doesn’t mean I spend my whole day sitting in front of the machine, working on Figma. While I might do that when deadlines are tight, what I do most of the time is think. I think a lot about potential solutions to everyday problems, and these solutions aren't just limited to software but extend to creating experiences that improve how we interact with the world around us.

I’ve worked in game development, app development, and web development throughout my college life, and one thing that unites them all—like the gears of a finely tuned machine—is design. A good design is something you don't just see; you feel it. A bad design, on the other hand, is both seen and felt, and not in a good way.

So, that’s where I come in. With my experience and creativity, I elevate design thinking into practical tools that can enhance your business. I have my solid engineering background to assist me in that (I develop as well). Whether you need innovative solutions or a fresh perspective on your existing tools, I’m here to help with consultation sessions designed to take your business to the next level.

(P.S. I love to participate in hackathons, cohorts, meetups etc. I like to hear what other people with similar mindset, thinks and feels.)

reason:
As a second-year B.Tech student in Mathematics and Computing at RGIPT, I may still be in the early stages of my open-source journey—but I believe that’s exactly what makes me an empathetic and effective mentor.
I remember the hesitation and confusion I felt when making my first contributions, and I understand how valuable guidance, encouragement, and community support can be. This is why I want to mentor at GSSoC 2025—not because I have all the answers, but because I’m committed to creating a safe, collaborative, and growth-oriented environment for contributors like me.
I strongly believe that mentorship is not a one-way transfer of knowledge, but a shared journey. While I help mentees navigate the process of understanding repositories, making PRs, and learning open-source tools, I will also be learning—sharpening my understanding, deepening my communication skills, and growing with the community.
I have already started mentoring juniors informally, explaining concepts, setting up GitHub for them, and motivating them to take part in tech programs. Through GSSoC, I want to scale that impact and help new contributors believe that they belong in tech, no matter their background or experience level.
Open-source is built on collaboration, learning, and sharing—and that’s exactly what I want to foster as a GSSoC 2025 mentor.

As a GSSoC mentor, my plan is to: (1) design a gentle onboarding path (setup + first PR in week 1), (2) run weekly office hours and async check-ins, (3) review PRs with actionable, example-driven feedback, and (4) insist on tests/docs so contributions remain maintainable. Success = each mentee lands ≥2 merged PRs and writes a short learnings note to help the next cohort. I’m committed to an inclusive, respectful environment and will stay active post-program.
